ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Throughout this course, I gained a stronger familiarity when conversing in Spanish. Since we were learning Spanish to learn more about Spanish concepts, rather than learning Spanish to learn Spanish, my understanding was really tested, which ensured that I was truly employing the skills I learned in high school.
I practiced written and spoken Spanish.
I developed my skills in Spanish reading comprehension, writing, and speaking while learning about environmental issues, discussing possible meanings of murals, and reading short stories.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this class is the wide variety of themes that we covered. I felt like my Spanish improved so much because of all the different vocab we had to use for each unit. Also, the strong emphasis on grammar, even though it wasn't a explicit part of the class, was helpful in polishing my conversational Spanish. It felt like a lot of the assignments were just busy work and it did not really increase my performance in class.

Strengths were the asynchronous day and the project/unit basis for the course, which divided it up into manageable chunks. Weaknesses were monotony in the class meetings, and that it was often difficult to participate in conversation if you're not one of the best speakers.

The workload isn't too bad but I wasn't totally engaged. I think it was hard to have the expected conversations and there wasn't a lot of accountability. I think there could be more grammar in the beginning, and maybe vocabulary sheets corresponding with the units? I just didn't always feel that I had the baseline to just delve into things in the conversations. It would have been more interesting if there was a stronger foundation or at least a review of L2 grammar.

I found the various project formats extremely helpful in both developing my Spanish and staying engaged with the content of the class. I also found asynchronous Wednesdays extremely helpful as a means of catching up on work in the middle of the week and completing my Spanish assignments in my own time. Sometimes the workload seemed a little excessive (especially nights including heavy reading).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I feel like most people who take this course are taking it because it is a graduation requirement, but regardless I think it did a good job of building on actual concepts related to learning Spanish and connecting that to the real world. I think if you have the chance to take this class, then you should.
Not especially; only if you need it for a language requirement or if you're really interested in learning/strengthening your Spanish.
I would highly recommend this course and professor to other students.
